data.title: Move line up drops a line
Support workspace settings in multi root environment
data.body:
We need to find a solution to allow for workspace settings in a multi-root environment. We cannot assume that one of the folders is the container for settings anymore.

Related: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29455

data.title: Multi root: decide where to store workspace information
data.body:
We should revisit where we store multi root metadata. Things to consider:
* free form setup of roots (no more master details)
* having a stable identifier to use for: UI state, API storagePath, API workspaceState
* how to identify windows on the main side that now requires a `workspacePath`?
* should we `realpath` the root configuration to be in sync with what we do today in the workbench startup?
* should we install watchers that notify when a root disconnects/connects and introduce a new event for this?
* how to share this?

Related: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29456

data.title: Tasks: Multi Root Support
data.body:
This issue is for discussing the future of tasks in a multi-root environment. I see two interesting places where today a single root is assumed (there may be more I am not aware of):
* when resolving the tasks configuration ([`getConfiguration`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/electron-browser/task.contribution.ts#L1279))
* when detecting tasks from files such as gulpfile.js ([`ProcessRunnerDetector`](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/node/processRunnerDetector.ts#L118))

`IWorkspaceContextService.toResource()` and `getWorkspace()` are deprecated in favour of `IWorkspaceContextService.getWorkspace2()` that contains information about all the roots.

We need to decide for tasks (and debug) if we just collect tasks from all workspaces or introduce a different concept to make this decision.

data.title: Test: Windows 64 bit
data.body:
- [x] Windows - @bpasero 
- [x] Windows - @kieferrm 

Complexity: 3 

Refer to https://vscode-builds.azurewebsites.net/ for downloads

### Archive

- Make sure the Windows 64 archive works well

### Setup

- 64 bit installer should block user if he already has 32 bit installed; and vice versa
- 64 bit installer should have updates working just as 32 bits. To simulate an update, simply close Code, change the `commit` in `product.json` and start up Code; you should get an update.

data.title: Test: preLaunchTask in debug
data.body:
- [x] any os - @egamma 
- [x] any os - @aefernandes 

Complexity: 3 

We have changed the task framework and now support a new `2.0.0` version. Have a `launch.json` with a `preLaunchTask` and verify that `preLaunchTask` behaves as expected both if you have a `2.0.0` version of `tasks.json` and if you have the old `0.1.0` verions of `tasks.json`.

Example workspace that has a `preLaunchTask`: a newly generated typescript vscode extension

data.title: Issue a error if version 2.0.0 defines global OS specific tasks.
data.body: This was never supported in 2.0.0 but a user might be hit when simply changing the version number. We should make this clear in the schema and issue an error message.

data.title: Add a way to retrieve last commit message

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Could be nice, in the source control panel, to be able to fill in the Message field with the last commit message.

It could speed up development for team running a task based flow with some commit message format rule. (ex: ISSUE-xxx - description)

data.title: Suggest primary build task

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body: We should keep track of the build task execution. If the same task is executed as the build task for 3/5 times in a row we should offer marking the task as the primary build task so that it executes on Ctrl+Shift+B

data.title: Decide on allowing children of a folder and their parent to be in same workspace
data.body:
We have to decide if the following structure is allowed in multi root:
```
myFolder
|_myChild
myChild
```

While it is possible for us to support this from the workbench point of view, we have to keep in mind that this travels to extensions and language servers and might make life harder for everyone to adopt this behaviour.

Alternatively we could disallow such setups where the same folder shows up N times.

data.title: Certain ANSI sequences can cause integrated terminal to start showing bold text when it shouldn't

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Windows 10, Build 15036

Version 1.14.0-insider
Commit 779a7dfa682e31d870680caea572a11d009ab447
Date 2017-06-23T05:59:57.891Z
Shell 1.6.6
Renderer 56.0.2924.87
Node 7.4.0

Something weird happens for me for quite some time now. It is that after certain output, all text starts to be bold in the integrated terminal, usually until some process is closed or in case of SSH until the session is closed. But it still may have some kind of "buggy state" afterwards, see below.

### Test case 1

1. Run **WSL bash** in integrated terminal
2. Open node (v8.0.0) REPL
3. Enter `12345` and press Enter. Everything is still okay, nothing is bold.
4. Enter `null` and press Enter. Note that the output word `null` is bold.
5. Enter `12345` and press Enter. Note that what you enter is now also bold (but the yellow text is not).
6. Exit by pressing Ctrl+C twice. Note that the output about having to press Ctrl+C twice is also bold.
7. Repeat the above steps 2-6 once more. Note that the problem has been resolved by quitting node, it will again work normally until step 4 is reached.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6010463/27534581-c62c8ed8-5a67-11e7-865f-84c14445bf58.png)

### Test case 2

Interestingly, this case behaves *slightly* different from test case 1 and shows that there is some kind of state which is not fully reset when existing the process which caused the bold text in the first place.

1. Run **Git bash** in integrated terminal.
2. *Same as above:* Open node (v8.0.0) REPL
3. *Same as above:* Enter `12345` and press Enter. Everything is still okay, nothing is bold.
4. *Same as above:* Enter `null` and press Enter. Note that the output word `null` is bold.
5. *Same as above:* Enter `12345` and press Enter. Note that what you enter is now also bold (but the yellow text is not).
6. *Same as above:* Exit by pressing Ctrl+C twice. Note that the output about having to press Ctrl+C twice is also bold.
7. Repeat steps 2-6 once more. You will notice that, unlike in test case 1, there is a subtle difference in the second iteration: In step 4, when you start typing `null`, **the text you type is already bold**. This is different from case 1, in which only the formatting of the output `null` triggered the bold text - now, also the yellow number output triggers the bold text, if the bug already has been triggered once before in the same shell session!

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6010463/27534662-1c3128ac-5a68-11e7-95bb-26947f5c3e1f.png)

I used `script` on a real linux machine (it's not working in WSL yet) to record the output of scenario 1 into a text file, see attachment. When `cat`ing that file, it causes exactly the same issue as in scenario 1. However, even when doing that in Git bash, it behaves as in scenario 1, not scenario 2.
[nodetest2.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1101755/nodetest2.txt)

These are the relevant escape sequences from the file:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6010463/27535147-e03d9a18-5a69-11e7-8af8-c9c104d22bd3.png)

data.title: Not being notified when a settings file from a root folder (Other than first)  is changed
data.body:
Enable experimental file watching service.

Set up multi-root workspace, say Root A, Root B.
Let's say Root B has a setting `"editor.lineNumbers" = "off"` in its `.vscode` folder.

Open a file from Root B, observe that line numbers are off.
Change the value of the setting to `"relative`" and save.

Expected: File from Root B should show relative line numbers
Observed: Nothing changes

Only works after refresh

data.title: Implement conditional visibility for custom views
data.body: Ability to define a condition when a custom view can be visible or not

data.title: Do not leak `workspace` setting in Stable
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/29433

We should not show hover help and suggest this setting. If a user manually inputs it then it is fine to respect it, so it should just be hidden.

![screen shot 2017-06-26 at 11 14 37](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1926584/27532465-b615ad2e-5a60-11e7-83ac-0f020d7f8f23.png)

data.title: Decide on multi root actions naming
data.body:
Today we have two actions around multi root that we should finalize on the naming:
* Add Root Folder
* Remove Root Folder

Alternatives:
* Add Folder / Remove Folder
* Add Folder To Workspace / Remove Folder from Workspace
* Add Workspace Folder / Remove Workspace Folder
* more?

@Microsoft/vscode feedback welcome

data.title: Test: Multi root does not leak in stable
data.body:
- [x] macOS - @joaomoreno 

Complexity: 2

This milestone we have introduced multi root workspaces only for insiders. To verify this does not leak in stable:
* Download the latest vscode stable build from (which is not yet released) https://vscode-builds.azurewebsites.net/builds/stable
* Verify you can not add additional folders to the workspace (using: file menu, context menu in explorer, command palette)

data.title: Icon change
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 SP1

Can we change the icon so that the middle of the symbol is not filled with white, and is instead see-through? I've attached some files I drew up of the new icon. One is actually a PNG the other is a .ico file disguised as a PNG because GitHub doesn't allow for the uploading of ICO files. Just change the extension and it should be fine. 
![vs icon](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29654835/27530003-e78876b8-5a13-11e7-8863-83fbdb900f72.png)
![vs icon - ico format](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/29654835/27530004-e789a11e-5a13-11e7-8a34-870da7e678ac.PNG)

data.title: Trying to compile VS Code under Windows results in
data.body:
```
P:\mseng\VSCode\vscode [master]> gulp --tasks-simple
module.js:598
  return process.dlopen(module, path._makeLong(filename));
                 ^

Error: The specified module could not be found.
\\?\P:\mseng\VSCode\vscode\node_modules\nsfw\build\Release\nsfw.node
    at Object.Module._extensions..node (module.js:598:18)
    at Module.load (module.js:488:32)
    at tryModuleLoad (module.js:447:12)
    at Function.Module._load (module.js:439:3)
    at Module.require (module.js:498:17)
    at require (internal/module.js:20:19)
    at Object.<anonymous> (P:\mseng\VSCode\vscode\node_modules\nsfw\lib\src\index.js:3:16)
    at Module._compile (module.js:571:32)
    at Object.Module._extensions..js (module.js:580:10)
    at Module.load (module.js:488:32)
```

This seems to be caused by the new nsfw module which we now use to compile vscode. Since we use that in gulp and not in vscode it should may be not compiled using the electron environment but the node environment.
